description: With a capacity of 3 million travelers per year, Agadir – Al Massira Airport gets its airport code from the city of *Aga*dir.
name: Agadir–Al Massira Airport

description: Located in Málaga, Costa del Sol Airport didn’t think MAL was a good option as “mal” means “bad” in Spanish. Instead, it opted to use letters from Mál*ag*a and a filler letter ‘*P*’.
name: Aeropuerto de Málaga-Costa del Sol

description: Once the site for the Mangere Aerodrome, New Zealand’s busiest airport is located in Mangere, a suburb of *A*uc*kl*and.
name: Auckland Airport

description: Almaty International is Kazakhstan’s largest international airport. It is located 15km northeast from the city of Almaty and was formerly known as *Al*ma-*A*ta Airport.
name: Almaty International Airport

description: Located in the city of Nørresundby, Aalborg Airport is the third largest in Denmark and serves the city of *Aal*borg.
name: Aalborg Lufthavn

description: Sochi International served as the main airport for the 22nd Winter Olympics held in Sochi in 2014. Its airport code comes from its home in the *A*dl*er*sky District.
name: Sochi International Airport

description: *Alb*any International was the first municipal airport in the United States. It is the major air center for the Capital Region, northeastern New York, and western New England.
name: Albany International Airport

description: Originally built in 1946, Aarhus Airport has since been the “temporary” primary airport for the city of *Aar*hus, despite being located in the city of Tirstrup nearly 50 kilometers away.
name: Aarhus Airport

description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. N*a*ntu*ck*et Memorial, then, used other letters in its name to get ACK.
name: Nantucket Memorial Airport

description: First established in 1955, the main airport for Adelaide, Australia gets its airport code from its home in *AD*e*L*aide.
name: Adelaide Airport

description: Opened in 1929 and still operating from its original location, Lehigh Valley International gets its airport code from its former name: *A*llentown–*B*ethlehem–*E*aston International.
name: Lehigh Valley International Airport

description: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International is named after India’s first Deputy Prime Minister. Its airport code honors its home in the beautiful city of *A*h*m*e*d*abad.
name: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International Airport

description: Originally named El Altet, Alicante–Elche Airport is the sixth busiest airport in Spain. Located in Elche, it serves the cities of Valencia, Murica, and *Al*i*c*ante.
name: Aeropuerto de Alicante-Elche

description: Named after Queen Alia, third wife to the late King Hussein, Jordan’s largest airport is located in Zizya, 30 km (20 mi) south of the capital city of *Amm*an.
name: Queen Alia International Airport

description: The name “Schiphol” came from the nearby Fort Schiphol, which translates to “ship grave” in English. Its airport code honors the city of *Ams*terdam.
name: Luchthaven Schiphol

description: In 2009, Anchorage International was renamed to honor U.S. Senator Ted Stevens, but its airport code still honors its home in *Anc*horage.
name: Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport

description: Eleftherios Venizelos Airport is named after the Cretan political leader and Prime Minister of Greece who pushed the development of Greek aviation. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *Ath*ens.
name: Diethnís Aeroliménas Athinón “Elefthérios Venizélos”

description: Stockholm’s airport is named *Ar*la*n*da, a made-up word combining “Arland”, another name for the nearby parish of Ärlinghundra, and “landa”, Swedish verb meaning “to land.”
name: Stockholm-Arlanda flygplats

description: Antwerp International is a small scale airport serving Belgium’s second biggest city. Its airport code refers directly to the city of *An*twe*r*p.
name: Internationale Luchthaven Antwerpen

description: Sri Guru Ram Das Jee International is named after Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru and founder of the city of *A*mri*t*sar. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.
name: Sri Guru Ram Das Jee International Airport

description: The Hartsfield-Jackson Airport honors former mayors Maynard Jackson and William B. Hartsfield. The airport code honors *Atl*anta and has become the city’s beloved nickname.
name: Hartsfield–Jackson International Airport

description: Once the location for Bergstrom Air Force Base (BSM), *Aus*tin-Bergstrom Airport opened in 1999 and took the airport code AUS from Mueller Airport which closed that same year.
name: Austin–Bergstrom International Airport

description: Formerly named after 1st Lt. Charles Williams of the U.S. Army Air Corps, Phoenix-Mesa Gateway is the lucky airport whose airport code honors its home state of *A*ri*z*on*a*.
name: Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport

description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International opted, then, to use other letters from K*a*lama*zo*o.
name: Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International Airport

description: Laurence G. Hanscom Field is named after a local aviator who was killed in a plane crash in 1941. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Bed*ford.
name: Laurence G. Hanscom Field

description: Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón International shares its name with the Peruvian aviator. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *A*re*q*ui*p*a.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón

description: Barcelona’s first airfield was built in 1916, but a new location in El Prat was chosen in 1918. The airport now uses the code BCN which stands for *B*ar*c*elo*n*a.
name: Aeropuerto de Barcelona-El Prat

description: Originally a National Guard air base during World War II, Bradley International is named after U.S. Air Force Lieutenant Eugene M. *B*ra*dl*ey.
name: Bradley International Airport

description: Husein Sastranegara International was built by Dutch settlers and named after Husein Sastranegara, aviator from West Java. Its airport code comes from an old spelling of the city of Bandung: *B*an*DO*eng.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Husein Sastranegara

description: Formerly named and commonly still called Aldergrove Airport, *B*el*f*a*s*t International is located between the villages of Killead and Aldergrove. It is the busiest airport in Northern Ireland.
name: Belfast International Airport

description: Previously known as *Be*l*g*rade Airport or Surčin Airport, it was renamed in 2006 in honor of Serbian scientist and inventor Nikola Tesla. It is the busiest airport in the former Yugoslavia.
name: Aerodrom Beograd - Nikola Tesla

description: Located in the suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon’s only commercial airport gets its three-letter airport code from the French spelling of Beirut: *Bey*routh.
name: Beirut–Rafic Hariri International Airport

description: Originally known as Godfrey Field, Bangor International was an army air field during and after World War II. Its airport code comes from its home in *B*an*g*o*r*.
name: Bangor International Airport

description: Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International shares its name with Alabama civil rights activist Fred Shuttlesworth, but it gets its airport code from its home in *B*irming*h*a*m*.
name: Birmingham–Shuttlesworth International Airport

description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Previously Elmdon Airport, *B*irming*h*am Airport’s name gives us the first two letters plus that helpful ‘*X*’.
name: Birmingham Airport

description: Opened for passenger travel in 1948, Bilbao Airport serves the Basque Country and northern Spain from the city of *Bi*lba*o*.
name: Aeropuerto de Bilbao

description: Lake Brooks Seaplane Base is a seaplane landing area on Naknek Lake in Katmai National Park. Its airport code comes from the nearby *B*roo*k*s *F*alls.
name: Lake Brooks Seaplane Base

description: Kota Kinabalu International is Malaysia’s second-busiest airport. Its airport code comes from its location on *B*orneo and in the city of Kota *Ki*nabalu.
name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Kota Kinabalu

description: Opened in 1939, New Mexico’s largest airport gets its name and airport code from its home in *A*l*b*u*q*uerque.
name: Albuquerque International Sunport

description: Suvarnabhumi Airport was named by King Bhumibol Adulyadej after the mythical golden kingdom said to be located in Southeast Asia. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *B*ang*k*o*k*.
name: Suvarnabhumi Airport

description: Located on the coast of Lancashire, Blackpool Airport was formerly known as Squires Gate Airport. Its airport code comes from the city of *Bl*ac*k*pool.
name: Blackpool Airport

description: First established as a flight school for the U.S. military, Augusta Regional has become a significant hub for the Central Savannah River Area (CSRA). Its airport code comes from the city of *A*u*g*u*s*ta.
name: Augusta Regional Airport

description: Kempegowda International was renamed in 2013 to honor the city’s founder, Kempe Gowda I. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Bengaluru: *B*anga*l*o*r*e.
name: Kempegowda International Airport

description: Previously know as Bloomington/Normal Airport, Central Illinois Regional was renamed in 1996 to reflect its central location. Its airport code honors its home in *B*loo*mi*ngton.
name: Central Illinois Regional Airport

description: Nashville International was originally named after Colonel Harry S. Berry. Codes with first letter ‘N’ were reserved for the U.S. Navy, so it used *B*erry Field *Na*shville to get BNA.
name: Nashville International Airport

description: El Dorado International may be named after the mythical city of gold, but its airport code comes from its home in *Bog*otá.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional El Dorado

description: Started during World War II, RAF Hurn was renamed in 1969 to *Bo*urnemout*h* Airport after the nearby town in southern England.
name: Bournemouth Airport

description: Formerly Jeffery Field, Logan Airport was renamed in 1943 to honor Edward Lawrence Logan, U.S. Army Lt. General and MA state representative. Its airport code honors its home in *Bos*ton.
name: Logan International Airport

description: Sultan Aji Muhammad Sulaiman International, formerly Sepinggan Airport, is the busiest airport in Kalimantan. It serves the nearby city of *B*alik*p*apa*n*.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Aji Muhammad Sulaiman

description: The Mumbai airport was previously named Sahar International, but it gets its three-letter code from the city’s former English name, *Bom*bay, changed in 1995.
name: Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport

description: Originally named (and often still called) Gowen Field, Boise Airport honored U.S. Army 1st Lieutenant Paul R. Gowen. Its airport code honors its home in *Boi*se.
name: Boise Airport

description: Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport honors the late entertainer Will Rogers and aviator Wiley Post whose plane crashed nearby in 1935. Its airport code honors its home in *B*a*r*ro*w*.
name: Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport

description: Renamed in 1999 to honor former President Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira, Brasília International gets its airport code from its home in the capital city of *B*ra*s*ília, *B*razil.
name: Aeroporto Internacional de Brasília–Pres. Juscelino Kubitschek

description: Built during World War II and originally called Fliegerhorst Melsbroek, Belgium’s largest airport is located between Zaventem and Machelen, northeast of *Bru*ssels.
name: Luchthaven Brussel-Nationaal

description: EuroAirport *B*a*s*e*l*-Mulhouse-Freiburg has two IATA codes (MLH is the other one). It is actually located in Saint-Louis, France but is one of only a few airports in the world operated jointly by two countries, in this case France and Switzerland.
name: EuroAirport Basel–Mulhouse–Freiburg

description: The Sultan Iskander Muda International serves the area near Banda Aceh. Its airport code refers to the nearby subdistricts of *B*lang Bin*t*ang and *J*antho.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Iskandar Muda

description: Still called “Ferihegy” for the surrounding neighborhood, *Bud*apest’s airport was renamed in 2011 to honor Hungarian composer Ferenc Liszt.
name: Budapest Liszt Ferenc Nemzetközi Repülőtér

description: M. R. Štefánik Airport, also called *B*ra*t*i*s*lava Airport, was renamed in 1993 after General Milan Rastislav Štefánik, whose aircraft crashed near Bratislava in 1919.
name: Letisko M. R. Štefánika

description: In 1920, Burlington Municipal Airport opened, honoring and serving the city of *B*urling*t*on, *V*ermont.
name: Burlington International Airport

description: Opened in 1926 as Buffalo Municipal, *Buf*falo Niagara International was rebuilt and renamed in 1997 to honor the oft-visited Niagara Falls.
name: Buffalo Niagara International Airport

description: In 2005, Gallatin Field was renamed to *B*o*z*ema*n* Yellowstone International in honor of the famous national park.
name: Bozeman Yellowstone International Airport

description: Bob Hope Airport has gone by six names since its opening in 1930. It was renamed most recently in 2003 to honor entertainer Bob Hope. Like two of its former names, its code refers to its location in the Los Angeles suburb of *BUR*bank.
name: Bob Hope Airport

description: Built in 1940 and originally named Lexington County Airport, Columbia Metropolitan gets its airport code from the nearby city of *Ca*yc*e*.
name: Columbia Metropolitan Airport

description: Originally built during World War II and known as Payne Airfield, Egypt’s busiest airport serves the capital city of *Cai*ro.
name: Cairo International Airport

description: Dedicated in 1946, Akron–Canton Airport is actually located in the city of Green, Ohio. Its airport code comes from the nearby cities of *C*anton and *Ak*ron.
name: Akron–Canton Airport

description: Guangzhou Baiyun International opened in 2004 as a replacement for the 72-year-old airport with the same name. Its airport code comes from Guangzhou’s former English name: *Can*ton.
name: Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport

description: Cambridge Airport, briefly known as Marshall Airport Cambridge UK, originally opened in 1938. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *C*am*b*rid*g*e.
name: Cambridge Airport

description: Calicut International is named after the city of Kozhikode, *C*ali*c*ut in English. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*J*’, often used as a filler letter.
name: Calicut International Airport

description: Often called just “Maiquetía” by locals, Simón Bolívar International is named after the former Venezuelan president. Its airport code stands for *C*ara*c*a*s*.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Maiquetia “Simón Bolívar”

description: Previously Dum Dum Aiport, Netjai Subhas Chandra Bose International was renamed in 1995 to honor the Indian freedom fighter. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Kolkata: *C*al*cu*tta.
name: Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport

description: First opened in 1956, Mactan–Cebu International is located in Lapu-Lapu City and serves greater Metro *Ceb*u.
name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Mactan–Cebu

description: Soekarno–Hatta International serves the capital city of Jakarta and honors Indonesia’s first president and vice-president. It receives its code from the *C*en*gk*areng district in the city of Tangerang, where it’s located.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Soekarno–Hatta

description: Renamed and officially opened in 1974, France's largest airport is named after *C*harles *d*e *G*aulle, former President and founder of the French Fifth Republic.
name: Aéroport de Paris-Charles-de-Gaulle

description: São Paulo/Congonhas Airport opened in 1936 and is named after the neighborhood where it’s located, Vila *C*on*g*on*h*as.
name: Aeroporto de São Paulo/Congonhas

description: Cologne Bonn Airport is christened after Konrad Adenauer, Germany’s first Chancellor following World War II, but its airport code comes from its home in *C*olo*gn*e.
name: Flughafen Köln/Bonn

description: Opened in 1930 as Lovell Field, Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Cha*ttanooga.
name: Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport

description: Used as a military airfield during World War II and the Korean War, Charleston International’s airport code comes from its home in *Ch*arle*s*ton, South Carolina.
name: Charleston International Airport

description: Before being renamed in 1997, The Eastern Iowa Airport was known as *C*edar Rap*id*s Municipal.
name: The Eastern Iowa Airport

description: McClellan-Palomar Airport is located in northwest San Diego county and is named after George McClellan, local aviator and civic leader.  Its airport code comes from its city of *C*ar*L*sba*D*.
name: McClellan-Palomar Airport

description: Originally Friendship International (perhaps the best airport name ever), *B*altimore/*W*ashington *I*nternational was renamed in 1973 and again in 2005 to honor Thurgood Marshall, former U.S. Supreme Court justice.
name: Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport

description: Hopkins International is named after former mayor William R. Hopkins. Its airport code honors its home in *Cle*veland.
name: Hopkins International Airport

description: Formerly Palmaseca International, Cali’s airport is named after Alfonso Bonilla Aragón, local civic leader and journalist. Its airport code comes from an early nickname: *C*a*l*ipuert*o*.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alfonso Bonilla Aragón

description: Opened in 1929, Port Columbus is now the second busiest airport in Ohio. Its three-letter airport code comes from its original name *C*olumbus *M*unicipal *H*angar.
name: Port Columbus International Airport

description: Formerly Morris Field Air Base, Douglas Airport was renamed in 1954 to honor former mayor Ben Elbert Douglas, Sr., but its airport code honors its home in *C*har*l*o*t*te.
name: Douglas International Airport

description: Named after former Brazilian President-elect Tancredo Neves, the airport that serves the Belo Horizonte metro area is located in the municipality of *C*o*nf*ins.
name: Aeroporto Internacional Tancredo Neves - Confins

description: Originally known as Berrechid Airfield, Mohammed V International’s airport code comes from its full name and location: *C*asablanca *M*ohammed V International Airport, *N*ouaceur.
name: Mohammed V International Airport

description: Cochin International is located in the city of Kochi, previously known as Cochin. Its airport code pulls letters from the new name, *Koc*hi, but reverses them.
name: Cochin International Airport

description: Located in the small town of Kastrup and founded in 1925, *C*o*p*en*h*agen Airport is one of the oldest civil airports in the world.
name: Københavns Lufthavn, Kastrup

description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. *C*hia*n*g Mai International, a major gateway to the north of Thailand, uses that helpful ‘*X*’ in its airport code.
name: Chiang Mai International Airport

description: Bandaranaike International is named after former Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike and is one of the busiest hub airports in South Asia. Its airport code honors the city it serves, *C*olo*mb*o.
name: Bandaranaike International Airport

description: Opened in 1954 to replace Wingfield Aerodrome, Africa’s third busiest airport is located in the city of *C*a*p*e *T*own, South Africa.
name: Cape Town International Airport

description: Brussels South Charleroi International started as a flying school in 1919. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *C*ha*rl*eroi.
name: Aéroport de Charleroi Bruxelles Sud

description: Yeager Airport is named after U.S. Army Brigadier General Chuck Yeager, but its airport code honors its home in *C*ha*r*leston, *W*est Virginia.
name: Yeager Airport

description: Rafael Núñez International is named after the former Colombian president who wrote the verses for the country’s national anthem. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *C*ar*t*a*g*ena.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Rafael Núñez

description: Serving the greater Cincinnati metro area, Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky's airport code comes from the nearby city of *C*o*v*in*g*ton.
name: Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport

description: Built in 1944 for the Brazilian Air Force, Afonso Pena International is named after Brazil’s 6th president. With the codes CUR and CUB already taken, *C*uriti*b*a subbed a ‘*W*’ for the ‘U’.
name: Aeroporto Internacional de Curitiba - Afonso Pena

description: Often called Culiacán Airport, Bachigualato Federal International is named after Bachigualato, the neighborhood where it’s located. Its airport code comes from *Cul*iacán, the city it serves.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Federal de Bachigualato

description: In 2010, Hazrat Shahjalal International was renamed to honor the Sufi saint Shah Jalal. Its airport code comes from a former spelling for the city of Dhaka: *Dac*ca.
name: Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport

description: Started as a satellite aerodrome during World War II, Cardiff Airport gets its airport code from its home in *C*ardiff, *W*a*l*es.
name: Maes Awyr Caerdydd

description: Da Nang International is located in *Da* Nang, the largest city in central Vietnam. Its code’s last letter likely comes from Quảng Nam-*Đ*à Nẵng, the province Da Nong belonged to before becoming an independent municipality in 1997.
name: Sân bay Quốc tế Đà Nẵng

description: Started in 1930 as Sholtz Field, Daytona Beach International evolved from an uncommonly successful beach airport. Located next to Daytona International Speedway, it serves the city of *D*ayton*a* *B*each.
name: Daytona Beach International Airport

description: Alejandro Velasco Astete International is named after the Peruvian pilot first to cross the Andes in 1925. It serves the city of Cusco, often spelled *Cuz*co.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alejandro Velasco Astete

description: Founded and named in 1917, Love Field honors U.S. Army pilot Moss L. Love. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Dal*las.
name: Dallas Love Field

description: In 1998, Washington National Airport was renamed to honor former U.S. President Ronald Reagan. Its airport code honors its home in *D*istrict of *C*olumbi*a*.
name: Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport

description: Until 1995, Stapleton International Airport served the *Den*ver area with airport code DEN. When Stapleton closed, the new airport switched from DVX to DEN.
name: Denver International Airport

description: Previously known as Palam Aiport, Indira Gandhi International was renamed in 1986 to honor the former Indian prime minister. Its airport code honors its home in *Del*hi.
name: Indira Gandhi International Airport

description: In 1952, Dayton Municipal was renamed to honor James M. Cox, former governor of Ohio. Its airport code honors its home in *Day*ton.
name: James M. Cox Dayton International Airport

description: Opened in 1999, King Fahd International is the world’s largest airport by land area. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *D*a*mm*am.
name: King Fahd International Airport

description: For decades Dallas and Fort Worth ran competing airports, but in 1969 construction finally began on a joint airport to serve the *D*allas-*F*ort *W*orth area.
name: Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport

description: Officially opened in 1965, Russia’s busiest airport serves the capital city of Moscow. It is actually located in the nearby town of *D*o*m*od*e*dovo.
name: Domodedovo International Airport

description: Originally Bangkok International, Don Mueang Airport was renamed when Suvarnabhumi Airport opened in 2006. It gave up its BKK code and received a new one derived from *D*on *M*ueang and carrying over the ‘*K*’ from the old code.
name: Don Mueang International Airport

description: Opened in 1943, Dnipropetrovsk International Airport is located 15 km southeast from the center of the city which gave it the name and the code - *Dn*ipropetrovs*k*.
name: Dnipropetrovsk International Airport

description: Initially located in the suburb of Brackel, the airport serving the eastern Rhine-Ruhr area was moved to the city of *D*or*tm*und after World War II.
name: Flughafen Dortmund

description: Opened in 1963, Dundee Airport gets its airport code from *D*u*nd*ee, Scotland’s fourth largest city.
name: Port-adhair Dhùn Dèagh

description: Often called “New Doha Airport,” Hamad International opened in May of 2014, replacing *Doh*a International Airport as the primary airport for Qatar’s capital city.
name: Hamad International Airport

description: Ngurah Rai International serves the tourist destination of Bali and is named for I Gusti Ngurah Rai, national hero of Indonesia. Its airport code comes from *D*en*p*a*s*ar, the capital of the island.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Ngurah Rai

description: Robin Hood Airport is named after the legendary outlaw of English folklore. Its airport code comes from the rest of its name, *D*oncaster *S*heffield *A*irport.
name: Robin Hood Airport Doncaster Sheffield

description: Francisco Bangoy International is named after Francisco Bangoy who donated the land on which the airport sits. Its airport code comes from its home in *D*a*v*a*o* City.
name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Francisco Bangoy

description: When Dubai International opened in 1960, the airport code DUB was already in use by Dublin, Ireland. *D*u*b*ai subbed an ‘X’ for the U, making its unique airport code of DXB.
name: Dubai International Airport

description: Opened in 1940, Ireland’s busiest airport is located in its capital city of *Dub*lin.
name: Aerfort Bhaile Átha Cliath

description: Shreveport Downtown Airport serves the city of Shreveport along with Shreveport Regional (SHV). Its airport code comes from its close proximty to the city’s *d*own*t*ow*n*.
name: Shreveport Downtown Airport

description: In 1998, Rhine Ruhr Airport was renamed to *Düs*seldorf International, but dropped the ‘International’ in 2013.
name: Flughafen Düsseldorf

description: During World War II Detroit’s airport was known as Romulus Field, but in 1947 it was renamed to *D*etroi*t*-*W*ayne Major Airport.
name: Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport

description: Previously the location for Turnhouse Aerodrome and RAF Turnhouse airfield, Scotland’s busiest airport is located in the city of *Edi*nburgh.
name: Port-adhair Dhùn Èideann

description: Eindhoven Airport is also a military airbase, hosting the European Air Transport Command and the Movement Coordination Centre Europe. Its airport code comes from its home in *Ein*dhoven.
name: Vliegbasis Eindhoven

description: Armenia’s busiest airport get its name from its home in Zvartnots, but its airport code comes from the nearby capital city of Yer*ev*a*n*.
name: Zvart'nots' Mijazgayin Odanavakayan

description: Originally a Royal Air Force station, East Midlands Airport is located in Castle Donington in the *E*ast *M*idl*a*nds of England.
name: East Midlands Airport

description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. N*ew*a*r*k, then, used the other letters in its name to make EWR.
name: Liberty International Airport

description: Built on the island of Vágar by the British Army during WWII, Vágar Airport is the only airport in the *Fa*ro*e* Islands.
name: Vága Floghavn

description: Named after former Minister of Public Works, Juan Pistarini, the Buenos Aires airport’s code comes from *Eze*iza Partido where the airport is located.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Ministro Pistarini

description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. K*ey* *W*est International, featuring one of the shortest runways in the U.S., opted for EYW.
name: Key West International Airport

description: Also known as Algarve Airport, Faro International opened in 1966. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Fa*r*o*.
name: Aeroporto Internacional de Faro

description: Before being renamed to honor Montana's natural beauty, Glacier Park International was known as *F*lathead *C*ounty *A*irport.
name: Glacier Park International Airport

description: Rome’s international airport honors the original Renaissance man, Leonardo da Vinci. It is often referred to as just *F*iumi*c*in*o* Airport, explaining its airport code of FCO.
name: Fiumicino – Aeroporto Internazionale Leonardo da Vinci

description: Hector International is named after Martin Hector, local businessman who donated the land on which the aiport now sits. It serves the nearby cities of *Far*go and Moorhead.
name: Hector International Airport

description: Located about 60 miles south of its namesake national park, Fresno Yosemite International Airport was renamed in 1947 from *F*resno *A*ir *T*erminal.
name: Fresno Yosemite International Airport

description: Formally known as Amerigo Vespucci Airport after the Italian cartographer, *Fl*o*r*ence Airport is located in the suburb of Peretola.
name: Aeroporto di Firenze-Peretola

description: Bishop International is named after former General Motors board member, Arthur Bishop, whose farmland later became the airport grounds. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *F*li*nt*.
name: Bishop International Airport

description: Opened in 1964, Madeira Airport is the only airport in the Portuguese archipelago Madeira in the Atlantic Ocean. It serves the capital city of *F*u*nc*hal.
name: Aeroporto da Madeira

description: Opened commercially in 1936, Germany’s busiest airport is located in the city of *Fra*nkfurt.
name: Flughafen Frankfurt am Main

description: Sioux Falls Regional is also known as Joe *F*o*s*s Fiel*d*, named after aviator and Medal of Honor recipient Joe Foss.
name: Sioux Falls Regional Airport

description: Opened in 1974, Manas International is named after Manas, the epic hero of the Kyrgyz people. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Bishkek’s former name: *Fru*nze.
name: Manas International Airport

description: Originally built by the U.S. Navy during World War II, Funafuti International now serves the capital city of *Fun*afuti with three flights per week.
name: Funafuti International Airport

description: Renamed in 1991, Fort Wayne International was previously named Baer Field, after Lieutenant Paul Baer, the first flying ace in U.S. military history. Its airport code honors the city of *F*ort *Wa*yne.
name: Fort Wayne International Airport

description: Guadalajara International’s ceremonial name honors Miguel Hidalgo, leader of the Mexican War of Independence. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *G*ua*d*a*l*ajara.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Guadalajara

description: Lokpriya Gopinath Bordoloi International is named after the freedom fighter and former first Chief Minister of its home state, Assam. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Guwahati: *Gau*hati.
name: Lokpriya Gopinath Bordoloi International Airport

description: Before being renamed in 1960, Spokane International was known as *Ge*i*g*er Field, honoring U.S. Army aviator, Major Harold Geiger.
name: Spokane International Airport

description: Gibraltar International is one of the “Most Extreme Airports” due to Winston Churchill Avenue directly intersecting the runway. Its airport code comes from its location in *Gib*raltar.
name: Gibraltar International Airport

description: Used as a military air base until 1976, Gan International gets its airport code from its home on the island of *Gan* in Addu Atoll.
name: Gan International Airport

description: Formerly known as Galeão Air Force Base, Galeão International was created in 1941 on *G*overnador *I*sland’s *G*aleão Beach in Rio de Janeiro.
name: Aeroporto Internacional do Galeão–Antonio Carlos Jobim

description: Known as HMS Sanderling during World War II and later as Glasgow Abbotsinch Airport, Scotland’s second busiest airport honors its home in *Gla*sgow.
name: Port-adhair Eadar-nàiseanta Ghlaschu

description: *G*i*mp*o International Airport, located in Gangseo-gu of Seoul, was the main airport for Seoul and South Korea until being replaced by Incheon International Airport in 2011.
name: Gimpo International Airport

description: *G*rand *J*unc*t*ion Regional is also called Walker Field, named after Walter Walker, a local publisher who helped raise funding and support for the airport’s development.
name: Grand Junction Regional Airport

description: Fes–Saïss Airport, or just Saïss Airport, serves the second-largest city in Morocco, Fes. It gets its airport code from the city’s alternate spelling: *Fez*.
name: Fes–Saïss Airport

description: Gainesville Regional, renamed in 1977, was previously known as John R. Alison Airport. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *G*ai*n*es*v*ille, Florida.
name: Gainesville Regional Airport

description: Built in 1965 and located near the village of Vilobí d'Onyar, Girona–Costa Brava Airport gets its code from the city of *G*i*ro*na.
name: Aeropuerto de Girona-Costa Brava

description: Austin Straubel International is named after U.S. Army Air Corps Lt. Col. Austin Straubel, the first Brown County aviator to die while in service. Its code comes from the city of *Gr*een *B*ay.
name: Austin Straubel International Airport

description: Originally opened in 1977, Göteborg Landvetter Airport is Sweden’s second-largest airport and gets its airport code from the city it serves: *Got*henburg.
name: Göteborg Landvetter Airport

description: Located in the city of Vantaa, Finland’s busiest airport was originally built for the 1952 Summer Olympics in *Hel*sinki.
name: Helsinki-Vantaan lentoasema

description: In December of 1999, Kent County International Airport was renamed to honor former President Gerald R. Ford. Its airport code honors its home in *Gr*and *R*apids.
name: Gerald R. Ford International Airport

description: The São Paulo Airport’s name honors former governor André Franco Montoro, but its airport code honors its home in *G*ua*ru*lhos.
name: Aeroporto Internacional Guarulhos–Governador André Franco Montoro

description: Started in 1919, Geneva International is partially located in both the municipalities of Meyrin and Le Grand-Saconnex. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, *G*ene*va*.
name: Aéroport international de Genève

description: Located in the town of Langenhagen, Hannover Airport’s code combines its home in *Ha*nnover and German aviator Karl *J*atho, who also lends his name to one of the terminals.
name: Flughafen Hannover-Langenhagen

description: In 2004, Baku’s airport was renamed and changed its airport code from BAK to GYD in honor of former Azerbaijan President Heydar Aliyev, sometimes spelled *G*a*yd*ar Aliev.
name: Heydar Aliyev International Airport

description: Hamburg Airport was opened in January of 1911 and serves Germany’s second-largest city, *Ham*burg.
name: Flughafen Hamburg

description: Opened in 1961, Hakodate Airport gets its airport code from its home in the city of *H*a*k*o*d*ate.
name: Hakodate Airport

description: Hong Kong International is located on the island of Chek Lap Kok and is often called Chek Lap Kok Airport. Its three-letter airport code stands for *H*ong *K*on*g*.
name: Hong Kong International Airport

description: Originally Hahn Air Base, Frankfurt–Hahn Airport gets its name and airport code from the nearby village of *H*a*hn* in Rhineland-Palatinate.
name: Flughafen Frankfurt-Hahn

description: Originally a postal airport which opened in 1943, Frank País Airport is now home to the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces Eastern Command. The airport gets its code from *Ho*l*g*uín, the city in which it’s located.
name: Frank País Airport

description: Up until 1952, the Tokyo Airport was officially named after Haneda, the former fishing town where it is now located. Many still call it the *H*a*n*e*d*a Airport.
name: Tokyo International Airport

description: Built during World War II for the Air National Guard, Westchester County Airport gets its airport code from three Westchester towns: *H*arrison, *P*urchase, and *N*orth Castle.
name: Westchester County Airport

description: Once named after aviator Howard Hughes, *Hou*ston’s oldest commercial airport was renamed in 1967 to honor former Texas governor William P. Hobby.
name: William P. Hobby Airport

description: Rajiv Gandhi International was named to honor the former Indian prime minister. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Hyd*erabad.
name: Rajiv Gandhi International Airport

description: *D*ulles *I*nternational *A*irport’s three-letter code was once DIA. When hand-written, it was often misread as DCA, another Washington airport. It was reversed to IAD to avoid confusion.
name: Dulles International Airport

description: In 1997 the airport was renamed after former President George H.W. Bush, but was previously known as *I*ntercontinental *A*irport *H*ouston.
name: George Bush Intercontinental Airport

description: Mattala Rajapaksa International is named after the Rajapaksas, a prominent political family. Its airport codes comes from its location near *H*ambantota, S*ri* Lanka.
name: Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport

description: The airport that serves the Seoul Metro Area is actually located on a man-made piece of land between Yeongjong and Yongyu islands, west of *I*n*c*heo*n*’s city center.
name: Incheon International Airport

description: Started in 1923 as a military airfield, Kyiv International’s terminal building wasn't built until 1949. Located in the neighborhood of Zhuliany, its airport code comes from the capital city of K*iev*.
name: Kyiv International Airport

description: Devi Ahilyabai Holkar is named after Maharani Ahilya Bai Holkar, Holkar Queen of the Maratha Empire. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *I*n*d*o*r*e.
name: Devi Ahilyabai Holkar Airport

description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Formerly named Mid-Continent Airport, W*ic*hi*t*a opted for ICT.
name: Dwight D. Eisenhower National Airport

description: Before being renamed in 1976, Indianapolis International was called Weir-Cook Municipal, honoring World War I flying ace Colonel Harvey Weir-Cook. Its airport code honors its home in *Ind*ianapolis.
name: Indianapolis International Airport

description: Originally built in 1940 as a Royal Air Force station, Inverness Airport is located in Dalcross, Highland and serves the city of *Inv*erness.
name: Port-adhair Inbhir Nis

description: The most remote airport in the world, Mataveri International serves as the main entry point for people visiting or living on Easter Island. Its airport code comes from the Spanish name for Easter Island, *I*sla de *P*as*c*ua.
name: Mataveri International Airport

description: Halim Perdanakusuma International is Jakarta’s primary airport for military, private, and government flights. It is named after Air Vice-Marshal and national hero Abdul *H*a*l*im *P*erdanakusuma for his service in World War II.
name: Bandar Udara Halim Perdanakusuma

description: Before being renamed in 1947, Honolulu International was known as John Rodgers Airport, honoring the World War II naval officer. Its airport code honors its home in *H*o*n*o*l*ulu.
name: Honolulu International Airport

description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Jacksonville International gets its code from its home city of *Ja*cksonville plus that helpful ‘*X*’.
name: Jacksonville International Airport

description: Turkey’s busiest airport honors the first president of the Republic of Turkey, Mustafa Kemal Atatürk. Its airport code honors the city of *Ist*anbul.
name: İstanbul Atatürk Havalimanı

description: Renamed in 2008, Benazir Bhutto International honors the former prime minister of Pakistan. Its airport code honors its home in the twin cities of Rawalpindi and *Is*lama*b*ad.
name: Benazir Bhutto International Airport

description: Agartala Airport is named after the capital of Tripura state in India. Its airport code comes the from new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, plus the city of *A*gartala.
name: Agartala Airport

description: Formerly Itami Airport, Osaka International was renamed following its return to Japanese control in 1959. While it serves Osaka, it is actually located in the city of *It*a*m*i.
name: Osaka International Airport

description: Veer Savarkar International is named after the Indian freedom activist Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. Its airport code comes the from new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, with the letter *Z* as filler.
name: Veer Savarkar International Airport

description: Wyoming’s busiest airport, the only commercial airport located inside a U.S. national park, gets its airport code from the nearby town of *Jac*kson.
name: Jackson Hole Airport

description: Chandigarh International is named after the union territory in northern India, also known as “The City Beautiful.” Its airport code comes the from new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, plus the city of *C*handigarh.
name: Chandigarh International Airport

description: Jaipur International is the only international airport in the state of Rajasthan. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Jai*pur.
name: Jaipur International Airport

description: King Abdulaziz International is named after the first monarch of Saudi Arabia, and because of its proximity to Makkah, is best known for its spacious Hajj terminal. Its airport code honors the city of *Jed*dah.
name: King Abdulaziz International Airport

description: Opened by The States of Jersey in 1937, Jersey Airport serves the Bailiwick of *Jer*sey in the Channel Islands. It serves about 1.4 million passengers annually.
name: Jersey Airport

description: In 1963, Idlewild Airport was renamed in dedication to *J*ohn *F*. *K*ennedy. Unlike many other airports, it also changed its three-letter airport code from IDL to JFK.
name: John F. Kennedy International Airport

description: Previously *J*oha*n*nes*b*urg International, O. R. Tambo International was renamed in 2006 to honor Oliver Tambo, former African National Congress President.
name: O. R. Tambo International Airport

description: Adisucipto International serves the Yogyakarta (previously anglicized *Jog*jakarta) metro area, and honors Agustinus Adisucipto, national hero and early figure in the Indonesian Air Force.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Adisucipto

description: Also known as Reykjavík-Keflavík Airport, Iceland’s largest airport is located near the town of *Kef*lavík and 50 km south of the capital city of Reykjavík.
name: Keflavíkurflugvöllur

description: Originally opened in 1959 and then reorganized in 1993, Boryspil International serves the capital of Ukraine, *K*iev, from the city of *B*orys*p*il.
name: Boryspil International Airport

description: Jinnah International is named after Muhammad Ali Jinnah, founder of Pakistan. Its airport code comes from its former name and home in the city of *K*arac*hi*.
name: Jinnah International Airport

description: Kualanamu International is the busiest airport in Sumatra, built to replace the Polonia Airport and opened in 2013. It serves the Kuala Namu region (sometimes spelled Kuala Nemu, or *K*uala *N*am*o*).
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Kualanamu

description: Opened in 1970 and originally known as Ke-āhole Airport, Kona International serves Kailua-Kona, usually referred to as just *Ko*n*a*.
name: Kona International Airport

description: Opened as an airfield in 1949, Tribhuvan International is named after Tribhuwan Bir Bikram Shah, former King of Nepal. Its airport code comes from its home city of *K*a*t*h*m*andu.
name: Tribhuvan International Airport

description: Krasnodar International, also known as Pashkovsky Airport, serves the southern *Kr*asnoda*r* region of Russia.
name: Krasnodar International Airport

description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Fully built on an artificial island, Kansai Airport gets its code from the *K*ansa*i* region, plus that helpful ‘*X*’.
name: Kansai International Airport

description: Capital Region International started passenger service in 1929. Located in DeWitt Township, it serves the capital city of *Lan*sing.
name: Capital Region International Airport

description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. LA (*L*os *A*ngeles) became LAX.
name: Los Angeles International Airport

description: Upon completion, Kuala Lumpur International replaced Subang Airport as *Ku*ala *L*umpur’s primary passenger airport. At the same time, it took the KUL code and Subang received a new code of SZB.
name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Kuala Lumpur

description: Labuan Airport serves the country of Malaysia and gets its airport code from the territory of *L*a*bu*an.
name: Lapangan Terbang Labuan

description: Formerly called Alamo Field, McCarron Airport was renamed in 1948 after Pat McCarran, a senator and author of the Civil Aeronautics Act. Its airport code honors its home in *Las* Vegas.
name: McCarran International Airport

description: Formerly known as Alvedro Airport, A Coruña Airport was inaugurated in 1963. Its airport code comes from the Spanish city of *L*a *C*oruña, *G*alicia.
name: Aeroporto da Coruña-Alvedro

description: Located in the Royal Docks and near London’s financial district, *L*ondon *C*it*y* Airport primarily serves business travelers. Recently though, it has started serving more leisure destinations.
name: London City Airport

description: Pulkovo Airport opened in the city of *Le*ningra*d* in 1932. In 1991, the city returned to its original name of Saint Petersburg and kept the airport code, now associated with LED lights for many visitors.
name: Aeroport Pulkovo

description: LaGuardia has had many names and the land it sits on was once an amusement park. Its current name comes from Fiorello *L*a *G*uardi*a*, former mayor of New York who championed its construction.
name: LaGuardia Airport

description: Located in the Horse Capital of the World, Blue Grass Airport opened in 1946. Its airport code honors its home in *Lex*ington, Kentucky.
name: Blue Grass Airport

description: Often called Liège-Bierset, Liège Airport is located in Grâce-Hollogne and serves the city of *L*iè*g*e, Bel*g*ium.
name: Liège Airport

description: Located in the town of Padang Matsirat, Langkawi International serves the *L*an*gk*awi islands in Malaysia. It hosts an international maritime and aerospace exhibition every two years.
name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Langkawi

description: Close to *L*ondon, *G*at*w*ick Airport is the second-largest airport in Britain. It’s the world’s busiest single-use runway and is named after Gatwick manor house that used to stand on the site.
name: Gatwick Airport

description: Renamed in 2003, Allama Iqbal International honors Muhammad Iqbal, poet-philosopher and advocate for the Pakistan Movement. Its airport code honors its former name and home in *L*a*h*or*e*.
name: Allama Iqbal International Airport

description: Opened in 1949, Lihue Airport is the primary airport on the Hawaiian island of Kauai. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Lih*ue.
name: Lihue Airport

description: Originally named *Lim*a-Callao Airport, Jorge Chávez International was renamed in 1965 to honor the Peruvian aviator.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Jorge Chávez

description: Milan Linate Airport is officially named Airport Enrico Forlanini after the Italian inventor. Its airport code comes from the village of *Lin*ate in the town of Peschiera Borromeo.
name: Aeroporto di Milano-Linate

description: *L*ondon *H*eath*r*ow takes its name from Heathrow, a hamlet north-west of where the (then) small airfield was started in 1929.
name: London Heathrow Airport

description: In 2007, Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport was renamed to honor Jože Pučnik, considered one of the fathers of Slovenian independence. Its airport code honors its home in *Lju*bljana.
name: Letališče Jožeta Pučnika Ljubljana

description: Chaudhary Charan Singh International is named after India’s sixth Prime Minister. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *L*uc*k*n*o*w.
name: Chaudhary Charan Singh International Airport

description: Formerly Lagos International, Murtala Muhammed International was renamed to honor assassinated head of state, General Murtala Ramat Muhammed. Its airport code honors its home in *L*ag*os*.
name: Murtala Muhammed International Airport

description: The highest international airport in the world, at 13,325 ft (4061 m), El Alto’s airport code honors the nearby city of *L*a *P*az, *B*olivia.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional El Alto

description: Still referred to as Adams Field, Arkansas’ largest airport is now named after former U.S. President Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary. Its aiport code honors its home in *Lit*tle Rock.
name: Bill and Hillary Clinton National Airport

description: Lviv Danylo Halytskyi International is named after 13th century King Daniel of Galicia. Its airport code comes from the Polish spelling of Lviv: *Lwó*w.
name: Lviv Danylo Halytskyi International Airport

description: Svalbard Airport gets its name from the city it serves. Its airport code comes from the nearby town of *L*ong*y*ea*r*byen.
name: Svalbard lufthavn, Longyear

description: In 2000, Lyon’s airport was renamed to honor French aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. Its airport code comes from its original name, *Ly*on *S*atolas Airport.
name: Aéroport Lyon-Saint-Exupéry

description: Chennai International is located in Tirusulam, a suburb of Chennai, but gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name, *Ma*dr*a*s, changed in 1996.
name: Chennai International Airport

description: Spain’s largest airport honors former Prime Minister Adolfo Suárez, but its airport code honors its home in the capital city of *Mad*rid.
name: Aeropuerto Adolfo Suárez Madrid-Barajas

description: Midland International is located between the cities of Midland and Odessa. Its airport code comes from its time as a training base during World War II, named *M*idland Army *A*ir*f*ield.
name: Midland International Air and Space Port

description: Once called Ringway Airport because of its location in the parish of Ringway, the UK’s third busiest airport serves the city of *Man*chester.
name: Manchester Airport

description: Formerly known as Freeland Tri-City Airport, MBS International is the third busiest airport in Michigan. Its airport code honors the three communities it serves: *M*idland, *B*ay City, and *S*aginaw.
name: MBS International Airport

description: Renamed in 1976, Orlando’s airport was originally a military airfield known as *M*c*Co*y Airforce Base, honoring Colonel Michael Norman Wright McCoy.
name: Orlando International Airport

description: Opened in 1973 and originally named Seeb International, the largest airport in Oman is located in the city of *M*us*c*a*t*.
name: Muscat International Airport

description: Portugal’s busiest airport is named for its neighboring parish, Portela, but its airport code comes from the capital city of *Lis*bon.
name: Aeroporto da Portela

description: Often called HIA incorrectly, Harrisburg International’s airport code comes from *M*i*d*dle*t*own, a nearby Harrisburg suburb.
name: Harrisburg International Airport

description: Before changing its name in 1972, Kansas City International was originally known as *M*id-*C*ontinent *I*nternational Airport.
name: Kansas City International Airport

description: Once called Central Airport and most commonly referred to as *Mex*ico City International, Mexico’s busiest airport is named in honor of 19th century president, Benito Juárez.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Benito Juárez

description: In 1969, Memphis Municipal Airport changed its name to “International”, presenting *Mem*phis as a hub for international travel and cargo.
name: Memphis International Airport

description: Located in the suburb of Tullamarine, Melbourne Airport is often called “Tullamarine Airport” or just “Tulla.” Its airport code comes from the city of *Mel*bourne.
name: Melbourne Airport

description: Mansfield Lahm Regional is home to Mansfield Lahm Air National Guard Base and hosts Mansfield Airport Day each year. Its airport code honors the city of *M*ans*f*iel*d*.
name: Mansfield Lahm Regional Airport

description: Previously known as Dannelly Field, Montgomery Regional is located in and serves the city of *M*ont*g*o*m*ery.
name: Montgomery Regional Airport

description: Once called Chicago Air Park and later Chicago Municipal, Midway International was renamed in 1949 to honor World War II’s Battle of *M*i*dw*ay.
name: Midway International Airport

description: Manchester Airport added “-Boston Regional” to its name in 2005 to serve as another option for Boston travelers. Its airport code still honors its home in *M*anc*h*es*t*er.
name: Manchester–Boston Regional Airport

description: Once known as the 36th Street Airport, the three-letter code MIA stands for *Mia*mi and not the popular initialism for “missing in action”.
name: Miami International Airport

description: General Mitchell International honors U.S. Army Air Service General Billy Mitchell, but its airport code honors its home in *M*ilwau*ke*e.
name: General Mitchell International Airport

description: Located in Norton Shores, construction on Muskegon County Airport began in 1931. Its airport codes honors its home in *M*us*k*e*g*on County, Michigan.
name: Muskegon County Airport

description: EuroAirport Basel-*M*u*lh*ouse-Freiburg has two IATA codes (BSL is the other one). It is located in Saint-Louis, France but is one of only a few airports in the world operated jointly by two countries, in this case France and Switzerland.
name: EuroAirport Basel–Mulhouse–Freiburg

description: Ibrahim Nasir International is named after the first president of the Maldives. It is located on Hulhule Island, near the capital island of *M*a*le*.
name: Ibrahim Nasir International Airport

description: The QCIA serves the Quad City Metro area spanning the border of Iowa and Illinois. Its airport code comes from the city it resides in, *M*o*LI*ne.
name: Quad City International Airport

description: Officially opened in 1945, Plaisance Airport was later renamed to honor former Prime Minister Seewoosagur Ramgoolam. It is located in the southernmost part of *M*au*r*iti*u*s.
name: Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam International Airport

description: Marseille Provence Airport is located in the commune of Marignane and was previously known as Marseille–Marignane Airport. Its airport code comes from the city it serves,  *M*a*rs*eille.
name: Aéroport de Marseille Provence

description: Formerly Truax Field, named after U.S. Army Air Forces Lieutenant Thomas L. Truax, Dane County Regional’s code honors its home in the city of *M*adi*s*o*n*.
name: Dane County Regional Airport

description: Formerly known as Speedway Field and Wold–Chamberlain Field, MSP is now named after Minnesota's twin cities, *M*inneapolis and *S*aint *P*aul.
name: Minneapolis–Saint Paul International Airport

description: Minsk National, formerly known as Minsk-2 (yes, there is a Minsk-1), is the primary airport in Belarus. Its code comes from the city of *M*in*s*k. The ‘*Q*’ works phonetically, but is used as a filler letter.
name: Minsk National Airport

description: Located in the town of Beek and previously known as Beek Airfield, Maastricht Aachen Airport serves the cities of *M*aa*st*richt, Netherlands and Aachen, Germany.
name: Maastricht Aachen Airport

description: In 2001, the airport was named after jazz legend Louis Armstrong, but was previously called Moisant Field, after aviator John Moisant. Its airport code came from the nearby *M*oisant *S*tock *Y*ards.
name: Louis Armstrong International Airport

description: Rarely called by its full name, Munich Airport is named after German politician Franz Josef Strauss. Its airport code honors its home near the city of *Mu*ni*c*h.
name: Flughafen München Franz Josef Strauß

description: Carrasco International is named after aviation pioneer General Cesáreo L. Berisso. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *M*onte*v*i*d*eo.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Carrasco/General Cesáreo L. Berisso

description: Originally named Manila International, Ninoy Aquino Airport was renamed in 1987 to honor assassinated Senator Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino, Jr. Its airport code honors the city it serves: *M*a*n*i*l*a.
name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Ninoy Aquino

description: A former U.S. Army air base during World War II, Laurinburg–Maxton Airport is known today primarily as an airliner graveyard. Its code comes in part from *M*a*x*ton, but the ‘*E*’ is more of a mystery and is likely a filler letter.
name: Laurinburg–Maxton Airport

description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Milan’s airport code comes from Cascina *M*al*p*ensa, where the airport got its start, plus that helpful ‘*X*’.
name: Aeroporto di Milano-Malpensa

description: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar International is named after the chief architect of the Indian Constitution. Its airport code comes from its home in city of *Nag*pur.
name: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar International Airport

description: France’s third busiest airport is named for the regions it serves: the city of *N*i*ce* and the Côte d'Azur (the French Riviera).
name: Aéroport Nice Côte d'Azur

description: Jomo Kenyatta International is named after Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya’s first president and prime minister. Its airport code comes from a combination of letters from the capital city of *N*air*ob*i.
name: Jomo Kenyatta International Airport

description: Opened in 1935, Newcastle International served 4.6 million passengers in 2014 making it one of the busiest in the United Kingdom. Its airport code honors its home in *N*ew*c*ast*l*e.
name: Newcastle International Airport

description: Chūbu Centrair International serves the Chūbu (central) region of Japan. Located in the city of *N*a*go*ya, it replaced Nagoya Airport in 2005 and inherited its airport code too.
name: Chūbu Centrair International Airport

description: Commonly still called Teesside International, Durham Tees Valley started as RAF *M*iddl*e*ton St. George in 1941. Some say its code comes from *M*iddleton *M*ilitary *E*stablishment, but the airport itself has said the second ‘M’ is a filler letter.
name: Durham Tees Valley Airport

description: Located in St Mawgan in Pydar, Newquay Cornwall Airport began as a civilian airfield in 1933. Its airport code comes from the town of *N*ew*q*ua*y* in Cornwall.
name: Newquay Cornwall Airport

description: Upon privitazation in 2004, New Tokyo International Airport was renamed in recognition of the city in which is located, *N*a*r*i*t*a.
name: Narita International Airport

description: Oakland International was the departure site for Amelia Earhart’s final flight in 1937. It now serves the eastern part of the San Francisco Bay Area (the East Bay) and the city of *Oak*land.
name: Oakland International Airport

description: Norwich International was opened during World War II as RAF Horsham St Faith and is located in the city of *N*or*wi*ch in Norfolk.
name: Norwich International Airport

description: Originally a French military airfield, Nantes Atlantique is located southwest of Bouguenais and serves the city of *N*an*te*s.
name: Aéroport Nantes Atlantique

description: Originally built in 1961, Odessa International serves Ukraine’s third largest city of *Od*e*s*sa.
name: Odessa International Airport

description: It may sound like an amusement park, but Will Rogers World Airport honors legendary cowboy and entertainer, Will Rogers. Its airport code honors its home in *Ok*lahoma *C*ity.
name: Will Rogers World Airport

description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. With ORC (and other OR- codes) already taken, W*or*cester opted for ORH.
name: Worcester Regional Airport

description: Eppley Airfield is Nebraska’s largest airport and honors hotel mogul Eugene C. Eppley. Its aiport code honors its home in *Oma*ha.
name: Eppley Airfield

description: Established in 1929, Ontario Municipal was renamed “International” in 1946. In 2006, the “LA” was added to avoid confusion with the Canadian province that shares the name *Ont*ario.
name: LA/Ontario International Airport

description: Before the airport was renamed after Medal of Honor recipient Edward O’Hare in 1949, it was known as *Or*char*d* Field Airport.
name: O’Hare International Airport

description: Portugal’s second busiest airport is named after former Prime Minister Francisco de Sá Carneiro. Its airport code comes from its home in Porto and its alternate English spelling: *Opo*rto.
name: Aeroporto Francisco Sá Carneiro

description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. N*orf*olk, then, used the next letters in its name to make ORF.
name: Norfolk International Airport

description: Kahului Airport is named after its home city, but its airport code honors Hawaiian-born pilot Bertram J. H*ogg*.
name: Kahului Airport

description: Located in the village of Ballygarvan, Cork Airport is one of the three primary airports in Ireland. Its airport code comes from the city of C*ork*.
name: Cork Airport

description: Once named Villeneuve-Orly Airport, France’s second busiest airport is partially located in both Paris communes Villeneuve-le-Roi and *Or*l*y*.
name: Aéroport de Paris-Orly

description: Norway’s busiest airport is actually located in Gardermoen, but its airport code honors the capital city of *Osl*o.
name: Oslo lufthavn

description: Ostend-Bruges International serves mainly as a cargo and charter airport. Its airport code honors its coastal home city of *OST*end.
name: Internationale Luchthaven Oostende-Brugge

description: Boasting the second largest terminal in the world, Beijing’s Capital Airport is near the city’s center. Its airport code comes from an older English spelling of Beijing: *Pek*ing.
name: Beijing Capital International Airport

description: Originally opened in 1936 and named Morrison Field, *P*alm *B*each *I*nternational was renamed in 1948, with a stint as Palm Beach Air Force Base from 1951-1962.
name: Palm Beach International Airport

description: Formerly named Bayan Lepas International, Penang International is located in the Bayan Lepas district in *Pen*ang, Malaysia.
name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Pulau Pinang

description: Bucharest’s airport honors Henri Coandă, inventor of the first jet engine and discoverer of the Coandă effect in fluid dynamics. Its airport code comes from the nearby city of *Ot*o*p*eni.
name: Aeroportul Internațional Henri Coandă

description: Oulu Airport is Finland’s second busiest airport and its airport code reflects its home in the city of *Oul*u.
name: Oulun lentoasema

description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. PD (*P*ortlan*d*) became PDX.
name: Portland International Airport

description: During World War II, Philadelphia Municipal Airport served as an Air Force training field. Since 1945, it has been serving *Ph*i*l*adelphia and the Delaware Valley.
name: Philadelphia International Airport

description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. *Ph*oeni*x* is one where the ‘X’ makes perfect sense.
name: Sky Harbor International Airport

description: Renamed in 1990, Newport News/Williamsburg International was originally named Patrick Henry Airport after Camp Patrick Henry, a former army base. Its code represents *P*atrick *H*enry *F*ield.
name: Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport

description: St. Pete–Clearwater International is named for the two cities it serves. Previously called Pinellas International Airport, but with PIA already taken, it took its code from *Pi*n*e*llas County.
name: St. Pete–Clearwater International Airport

description: Started as a training airfield in 1934, Glasgow Prestwick Airport claims to be the only place in the U.K. Elvis Presley ever set foot. Its airport code comes from its home in *P*restw*i*c*k*.
name: Glasgow Prestwick Airport

description: Opened in 1952, the “Greater Pitt” Airport serves and honors the city of *Pit*tsburgh.
name: Pittsburgh International Airport

description: Commonly called Son Sant Joan Airport, Palma de Mallorca Airport gets its airport code from its location in *P*alma on *M*allorca *I*sland.
name: Aeropuerto de Palma de Mallorca

description: Pune airport is named after its home in the city of *P*u*n*e. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.
name: Pune Airport

description: Originally built in the 1940s and named Durian River Airport, Supadio International serves the city of *P*ontia*n*a*k* in West Kalimantan.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Supadio

description: In 2011, Pensacola Gulf Coast Regional was renamed to Pensacola International, still serving the city of *P*e*ns*acola and its surrounding areas.
name: Pensacola International Airport

description: Opened in 1931, Piarco International is located in the town of Piarco, but serves the capital city of *P*ort *o*f *S*pain.
name: Piarco International Airport

description: In 2012, Prague Ruzyně International was renamed to honor Václav Havel, the Czech Republic’s first president. Its airport code honors its home in the capital city of *Pr*a*g*ue.
name: Letiště Václava Havla Praha

description: T.F. Green Airport, as it’s called for short, honors former Rhode Island governor Theodore F. Green. Actually located in the nearby city of Warwick, its airport code reflects the major city it serves: *P*ro*v*i*d*ence.
name: Theodore Francis Green Memorial State Airport

description: Inaugurated in 1947, Tocumen International gets its name from the nearby Tocumen River. Its airport code comes from its home in *P*anama Ci*ty*.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Tocumen

description: The US Navy built Naval Air Station *P*a*sc*o during World War II. After the war, the Navy sold the field to the city of Pasco and it was redeveloped into Tri-Cities Airport.
name: Tri-Cities Airport

description: The airport serving the original Portland (in Maine) started as small Stroudwater Field, later renamed to *P*ortland-*W*estbrook *M*unicipal Airport.
name: Portland International Jetport

description: Shanghai Pudong International opened in 1999. Its airport code comes from the Shanghai district of *P*udon*g* with a filler ‘*V*’ replacing the ‘U’ to get PVG.
name: Shanghai Pudong International Airport

description: Marrakesh Menara Airport gets part of its name from the nearby Menara Gardens and the other part from its home in the capital city of Mar*rak*esh.
name: Marrakesh Menara Airport

description: Opened in 1943, Raleigh-Durham International is located in Wake County in between the cities of *R*aleigh and *Du*rham.
name: Raleigh–Durham International Airport

description: Recife International’s full name honors the Battle of Guararapes during the Dutch-Portuguese War and Brazilian sociologist Gilberto Freyre. Its airport code honors its home in *Rec*ife.
name: Aeroporto Internacional do Recife/Guararapes–Gilberto Freyre

description: While actually located in Salé, Rabat–Salé Airport gets its airport code from the Moroccan capital city of *R*a*ba*t.
name: Rabat–Salé Airport

description: Originally dedicated in 1927 as Richard Evelyn Byrd Flying Field, *Ric*hmond International Airport is the busiest airport in central Virginia.
name: Richmond International Airport

description: With the airport code RIV already taken by March Air Force Base in Riverside, California, Riverton Regional took its code from *Ri*verton and switched a ‘*W*‘ for the ‘V’.
name: Riverton Regional Airport

description: Started in 1917 as Camp Grant, Chicago Rockford International achieved international status in 2004. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *R*ock*f*or*d*.
name: Chicago Rockford International Airport

description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Riga International was built relatively recently in 1973, so its airport code comes from *Ri*ga plus that helpful ‘*X*’.
name: Starptautiskā lidosta “Rīga”

description: Roanoke-Blacksburg Regional is also known as Woodrum Field after former U.S. Representative Clifton A. Woodrum. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Roa*noke.
name: Roanoke–Blacksburg Regional Airport

description: Located in the township of Mingaladon, Myanmar’s primary international airport serves the city of Yangon. Its airport code comes from an English spelling of Yangon: *R*an*g*oo*n*.
name: Yangon International Airport

description: Originally built in 1925, Rostov-on-Don Airport became an international hub in 1986. Its airport code honors its home near the city of *Ro*sto*v*-on-Don.
name: Aeroport Rostov-na-Donu

description: Formerly known as Mana Airport, Swami Vivekananda International was renamed in 2012 to honor the well-known Indian saint. Its airport code honors the city it serves: *R*ai*p*u*r*.
name: Swami Vivekananda International Airport

description: Well known for its Sonny Bono Concourse named after the late entertainer, *P*alm *Sp*rings International has been called one of America’s “Most Stress-Free Airports.”
name: Palm Springs International Airport

description: Renamed “International” in 1993, Fort Myers’ airport was originally regional only. It takes its airport code from *R*egional *S*outh*w*est.
name: Southwest Florida International Airport

description: Opened in 1956, Rotterdam Airport was the Netherlands’ second national airport and was built in part to replace Waalhaven Airport, destroyed during World War II. Its code comes from the city of *R*o*t*terda*m*.
name: Rotterdam The Hague Airport

description: The original Rochester Airport was built in 1928 by the Mayo Foundation. Later renamed to Lobb Field, the airport was closed in 1961 and replaced by the current *R*oche*st*er International.
name: Rochester International Airport

description: Rzeszów–Jasionka Airport is located in southeastern Poland. Although situated in the village of Jasionka, its airport code comes from the nearby city it serves: *Rze*szów.
name: Port Lotniczy Rzeszów-Jasionka

description: Following Charles Lindbergh’s historic flight, the city where his plane was built capitalized on public support to build its own airport. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, *San* Diego.
name: Lindbergh Field

description: The gateway for south central Texas, San Antonio International was originally known as Alamo Field. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *S*an *A*ntonio, *T*exas.
name: San Antonio International Airport

description: Despite having “International” in its name, Savannah/Hilton Head airport has no scheduled commercial flights outside the U.S. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Sav*annah.
name: Savannah/Hilton Head International Airport

description: Built on a former cow pasture, Santa Barbara Municipal gets its airport code from its home in the *S*anta *Ba*rbara/Goleta metropolitan area.
name: Santa Barbara Municipal Airport

description: Opened in 1933 as Bendix Field, South Bend International was once called Michiana Regional (a combination of Michigan and Indiana). Its airport code honors its home in *S*outh *B*e*n*d.
name: South Bend International Airport

description: Often called “Pudahuel Airport”, Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez International honors the founder of the Chilean Air Force. Its airport code honors its home in *S*antiago, *C*hi*l*e.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez

description: Santiago de Compostela Airport is the second-busiest in Spain. Its airport code comes from its home near *S*antiago de *C*ompostela, plus a ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.
name: Aeroporto Internacional de Santiago de Compostela

description: Serving London and its surrounding areas, London Southend Airport is situated between the towns of *S*outh*en*d and Rochford.
name: London Southend Airport

description: “Sea-Tac” was once renamed after U.S. Senator Henry M. Jackson for a short while, but *Sea*ttle and Tacoma residents voted to keep their cities in the airport’s name.
name: Seattle–Tacoma International Airport

description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. *S*an *F*rancisc*o* instead used its last letter ‘O’.
name: San Francisco International Airport

description: Originally known as Calabouço Airport, Santos Dumont Airport was inaugurated in 1936 and was named after Brazilian aviator Alberto *S*antos-*Du*mont.
name: Aeroporto Santos Dumont

description: Before being renamed in 1995, Louisville International was known as *S*tan*d*i*f*ord Field, honoring former state senator Elisha David Standiford.
name: Louisville International Airport

description: Skagway, originally Skagua in Tlingit for “windy place”, was the largest city in Alaska by 1898 because of the Yukon gold rush. Its airport’s code honors its home in *S*ka*g*wa*y*.
name: Skagway Airport

description: Shanghai Hongqiao International was the first airport built in Shanghai. Its airport code makes sense as *S*hanghai *H*ongqiao *A*irport, but comes from the city of *SHA*nghai.
name: Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport

description: Operational since 1931, Shreveport Regional Airport’s code honors its home in the city of *Sh*re*v*eport.
name: Shreveport Regional Airport

description: Tân Sơn Nhất International is named for the township in which it’s located, but serves Ho Chi Minh City. Its airport code comes from Ho Chi Minh City’s former name: *S*ai*g*o*n*.
name: Tân Sơn Nhất International Airport

description: Often called just Changi Airport, *Sin*gapore’s main airport was named Skytrax “Best Airport in the World” three years in a row.
name: Lapangan Terbang Changi Singapura

description: In 2001, San Jose International was renamed to honor former mayor Norman Mineta. Its airport code honors its home in *S*an *J*ose, *C*alifornia.
name: Norman Y. Mineta San Jose International Airport

description: Juan Santamaría International honors Juan Santamaría, national hero of Costa Rica who was killed in the Second Battle of Rivas in 1856. Its code comes from the city it serves, *S*an *JO*sé
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Juan Santamaría

description: Originally named Woodward Field after local aviator John P. Woodward, Utah’s busiest airport now gets its name and airport code from state capital *S*alt *L*ake *C*ity.
name: Salt Lake City International Airport

description: Luis Muñoz Marín International is named for Puerto Rico’s first democratically elected governor. Although actually located in Carolina, its airport code reflects the capital city of *S*an *Ju*an.
name: Aeropuerto Internacional Luis Muñoz Marín

description: When Sacramento International was built, the airport code SAC was already taken by (then named) Sacramento Municipal Airport. So it took its code from its original name, *S*acramento *M*etropolitan *F*ield.
name: Sacramento International Airport

description: In 1979, Orange County Airport was renamed to honor John Wayne, legendary actor and resident of nearby Newport Beach. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *S*a*n*ta *A*na.
name: John Wayne International Airport

description: After World War II, Shannon Airport became the primary gateway for transatlantic flights to and from the U.S. Its airport code honors its home in the town of *S*ha*nn*on.
name: Shannon Airport

description: Adisumarmo International honors Adisumarmo Wiryokusumo, national hero and pioneer of the Indonesian Air Force. It serves the city of Surakarta, also known as *So*lo *C*ity.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Adisumarmo

description: Located in the Borough of Eastleigh, Southampton Airport was the site for the first Supermarine Spitfire test flight in 1936. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Sou*thampton.
name: Southampton Airport

description: Formerly Resnik Airport, Split Airport gets its first two letters from the city it serves, *Sp*lit. The ‘U’ isn't as clear, but could come from “*S*alonae *P*alati*u*m”, long-believed (erroneously) to be the origin of the city’s name.
name: Zračna luka Split

description: Opened during World War I and originally named San Carlos Flying Field, SQL is often misattributed as a reference to the nearby database company, Oracle. It actually stands for *S*an Car*l*os plus a helpful filler ‘*Q*’.
name: San Carlos Airport

description: Once a military airbase for the Armed Forces of Indonesia, Ahmad Yani International serves *S*ema*r*an*g* and its surrounding areas. It honors General Ahmad Yani, a major figure in the Indonesian National Revolution.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Ahmad Yani

description: Stinson Municipal was established in 1915 by aviators and teachers Katherine, Eddie, and Marjorie Stinson. Its airport code comes from its original name and purpose as *S*tinson *S*chool of *F*lying.
name: Stinson Municipal Airport

description: Often called Sofia-Vrazhdebna Airport, Bulgaria’s primary airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *Sof*ia.
name: Letishte Sofiya

description: Built in 1927, Holman Field was named after airline and stunt pilot Charles W. Holman. Today, the airport is known as the *St*. *P*aul Downtown Airport.
name: St. Paul Downtown Airport

description: Started as an airfield during World War II, London *St*a*n*sted Airport opened its first commercial terminal building in 1969 and is a base for many major European low-cost carriers.
name: London Stansted Airport

description: Stuttgart Airport was renamed in 2014 to honor former mayor Manfred Rommel. It is the sixth busiest airport in Germany and serves the city of *St*uttga*r*t.
name: Flughafen Stuttgart - Manfred Rommel Flughafen

description: In 2000, Charles M. Schulz Airport was renamed to honor the famed “Peanuts” cartoonist, a longtime resident of Sonoma County. The airport’s code recognizes the city in which it is located, *S*an*t*a Ro*s*a.
name: Charles M. Schulz - Sonoma County Airport

description: Lambert-St. Louis International is named after Albert Bond Lambert, Olympic golfer and the first to receive a pilot's license in the city of *St*. *L*ouis.
name: Lambert–St. Louis International Airport

description: Friedman Memorial is named after the Friedman family who donated the land to the city of Hailey in 1931. Its airport code comes from the nearby resort community it serves: *Sun* Valley.
name: Friedman Memorial Airport

description: Juanda International is the second-busiest airport in Indonesia. It is named after the last Indonesian Prime Minister, Djuanda Kartawidjaja, but gets its airport code from the city it serves: *Su*ra*b*aya.
name: Bandar Udara Internasional Juanda
